reviews.review: I have no complaints. Excellent game. Buy it, BUY IT NOW!

As the ending credits rolled, I found myself left with goosebumps and a feeling of emptiness - exactly what you'd want from this genre. I haven't played the first or second in the series, but I sure want to check out the remastered versions now! Great writing for a unique, dark, steampunky world shrouded in fatalism, with an endearing and useful NPC. As action FPS games go, this one's a winner.
amazing graphics and wonderful story, enjoyed playing the game
FUC***G AWESOME GAME. Great plot, good gameplay, you finish it right before it gets tiresome, it's just one of the best games ever made. That's it.

This video game is a masterpiece. In my opinion it is one of the video games with the best history that I have ever tried. The setting, the gameplay, the graphics and the design of the characters seem incredible to me. This is one of the games that I would recommend to always play to anyone who wants to see the best of the medium.
Nothing more to add, if you plan to buy the video game I hope that my review helps you decide to do it, it is an experience worthwhile.

Fast paced gameplay especially when compared to the other 2 games. The weapon system is a strange combination of bioshock 2's dual weilding with a weapon swapping mechanic which always kept me on my toes to get ammo or a different gun. Some weapons felt underpowered while others felt extremely powerful [spoiler] (i.e. the hand cannon is the only sidearm you will need. The skyhook......not so much) [/spoiler] a really really good entry in the series that i only wish i picked up sooner.

[spoiler] and wow, did the ending take me by surprise. like yes the ending was hinted at a LOT througout the game, but even with knowledge of how it ended, i still was surprised in a lot of turns i did not expect in the slightest. overall, my original point still stands [/spoiler]

Overview
Bioshock Infinite is the series' third chapter, set in the early 1900s in a new location, rather than the usual Rapture. Players impersonate private detective and war veteran Booker DeWitt, which is forced to accept a dangerous assignment in order to pay off his debts. Such mission entails finding and retrieving a young woman named Elizabeth from a hidden, flying city called Columbia. Booker's intrusion isn't taken too well, and himself along with Elizabeth will have to go through many dangers in order to escape.

ğŸŸ© The Good Side
A Jewel in the Skies
The aesthetics of Infinite and in particular Columbia itself, are nothing short of amazing. Each environment, street, room and plaza is rich with details, while the landscapes and vistas coupled with high-end light effects create true magic. This title nails the representation of an apparently utopistic city (such as Rapture was, at a first glance) which then the player discovers to be plagued by massive problems: in the case of Columbia racism, inequality and borderline slavery are just some. Effects, weapons and animations complete the picture and as well contribute in delivering stunning visuals at all times.

It might be a good shooter...
Gameplay-wise, the game offers fluid and satisfying FPS combat, with each weapon having a distinct feel and good kick behind shots, impacts. The inclusion of the series' iconic powers, this time named Vigors, adds some variety of approach to each fight. There are new gameplay systems not seen before in the series, such as the use of a hook to traverse ziplines, and having a companion that regularly supplies you with ammo and resources. The pacing of combat as well is more action-oriented than in the previous entries with quick-witted enemies and less forgiving shooting.

https://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=2228008459

ğŸŸ¥ The Bad Side
...but not a good Bioshock
Despite a solid combat system, this third installment takes away everything else that made Bioshock... Bioshock. Level design is far less complex and more linear, secrets and secondary locations streamlined and cut away to a fraction of what was seen in the previous entries. Crafting is gone, powers have been reduced to a mere eight (some of which are borderline useless too), enemies feel more generic than ever. Character building possibilities and variety of approaches to situations are massively reduced as well, streamlining each area to little more than a shooting gallery as in any other regular FPS.

Time Travel? QUANTUM MECHANICS?! 300 IQ Story!
Infinite starts out admittedly well, to then become an increasingly complicated (quantum?) entanglement of events that by the end of it, straight out crash into conflicting paradoxes. This game takes into account concepts such as time traveling, alternate realities, Einstein-Rosen bridges (wormholes) and mashes them together in the most casual way possible... almost as if adding QUANTUM to anything instantly makes it "deeper". That is the strong impression the writing left to me. INFINITE-ly worse than the previous two games' well-thought out narratives.

Seriously, who are these guys?
The characters encompassing Infinite's storyline are as generic as they can be, including the two protagonists. There is your stereotypical industrialist hell-bent to justify legal slavery with moralist concepts, your run-of-the-mill anarchist that wants revolution but doesn't have a plan to actually run the country any better. Then we have Booker, more automaton than man, managing to utter around twelve complete sentences in the whole game, and appearing dull as ever with each. Forget the previous games' well thought out and deep characters.

Rating: Above Average
It took me 10 hours to complete the game on Hard, taking my time to find secrets in each area. For the current price of 30â‚¬, decent overall quality yet several issues, I would suggest waiting a good sale before buying - especially for fans of the series.


In-Depth Breakdown
ğŸ® Gameplay Analysis
Gameplay is divided into Exploration and Combat.

Exploration
Is performed mostly on foot, and on occasion by using your Hook tool to traverse metal rails or jump on cargo holding platforms. There isn't any map to consult to get a sense of direction, but the linearity of levels doesn't warrant that anyway. Each location is filled to the brim with containers such as barrels, crates, purses and more - not to mention corpses at times. Looting everything you can find will give you cash, health, salts, ammo and sometimes more rare resources like lockpicks.

There are secrets to find such as secondary rooms a little off the main path, and in a few cases code ciphers to decipher after finding the relative book, usually in another part of the level. Vendors are uncommon and usually offer upgrades for your weapons, powers other than ammunition or health. Hacking is gone entirely, so no discounts this time! Infusions are rare items boosting Booker's stats permanently, and often are located behind lockpick-able doors or cipher rooms.

Combat
Plays out in an FPS fashion, and is admittedly solid at that: satisfying fluidity of actions, good animations, plenty of gore, weight behind shots and deadly enemies. As the adventure goes on, you'll access a good variety of weapons and powers, all with their relative upgrades that however will almost never feel unique. Gear is an important part of combat, granting Booker passive abilities, it can be changed at any time to better suit a specific situation but in general, the really 'good' pieces of gear are few.

Enemy variety is not very good, and most foes will feel too similar to each other. Most of all combat disappoints because it has a rather narrow amount of ways to play out, especially considering what the previous titles offered in this regard. It's still solid, though. Death will mean losing some money but being revived on the spot, enemies will get back Full Hp though - still rather cheesy. The level of interaction with the environment is much less than in the other series entries, and is a letdown.

https://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=2228759258

Technical Breakdown
PC Specs: RTX2080Ti, Ryzen 3900X, 32GB RAM DDR4

Critical Problems
None.

Optimization
Not good. Despite not being a new game at all, it consumes 50% of a 2080Ti on average, while if alt-tabbed, consumes a blistering 90-100% GPU at all times for unknown reasons.

Performance
The game runs without issues in 1440p, 85Hz.

Bugs
No major bugs to report.

Other Issues
None.

Llevo 15 minutos jugados, Se puede cambiar el brillo y SE PUEDE CORRER, LE METIERON EL ALMA Y CORAZON A ESTA ENTREGA, ya solo por estas 2 cosas es el mejor BioShock de todos.

Solo me faltan los Dlc's pero la campaÃ±a principal es muy buena, puede que llegues a no entender nada en el final, que pienses que todo es un sueÃ±o y que el prota se despertara sin piernas, aun siendo asi es muy creativa y muy recomendable.

Solo en el final se "conecta" con las demas entregas de Bioshock pero es de una manera tan leve que se podria llamar "otro FPS con poderes", aunque es un FPS muy comodo con una jugabilidad decente, y los vigores le da un plus aunque no los uses.

Y si, EL MEJOR BIOSHOCK DE TODOS, ningun bug que me molestara y que me quitara las ganas de jugar, no como los otros 2 remastered.
9 straight hours. fun game, good story.
Tam anlamÄ±yla mÃ¼kemmel. Tek sorunu detaylÄ± bir hikayesi olmasÄ±na karÅŸÄ±n kÃ¶tÃ¼ bir anlatÄ±mÄ± var.

There are multiple reasons to praise this game, and the whole Bioshock series in fact. If I would have to choose a favorite from the three games, it would however be this one. The graphics are spectacular, even though the game was released 7 years ago, and the story is amazing. One of the best thing in game is Elizabeth, who - besides having a compelling and loveable character - is one of the few NPCs who actually helps you during combat, and does not get in the way at all. I think the whole Bioshock collection is a must play, because these three games show that a video game can be an artistic masterpiece.

It's a slow burn, but it makes up for the chills and goosebumps later on. As much as I liked the first game, it never really c(r)aptured me in a way this game did. Maybe it was Elizabeth and her sob story, or maybe it was just the world of Columbia that seemed more appealing to me. Words can't recommend this game enough, but numbers can. #77/10. 

POST BURIAL AT SEA - Episode 1 is a joy, but Episode 2 has some pacing issues ( not to mention gameplay issues ) but in typical Bioshock fashion, it is all worth it in the end.

Excelente juego, buena historia, buena jugabilidad y excelentes locaciones.

Es un juego impresionante! La historia es atrapante y desde que inicia el juego tienes interÃ©s de la historia del mundo en donde se desarrolla el juego y de los personajes, pues el juego no solo con cinemÃ¡ticas o diÃ¡logos vas a conocer de la historia ya que cuenta con audios que revelan mÃ¡s informaciÃ³n que te ayudarÃ¡n a entender el contexto.
La jugabilidad es rÃ¡pida y con un gran agregado de que tu compaÃ±era de equipo no es una carga como en algunos juegos ya que ella interactÃºa con el lugar para ayudarte a cambiar la estrategia o proveerte ayuda.
En el arte la mÃºsica es muy buena y en la parte del visual de como es el mundo y sus personajes es de lo que estarÃ¡s impresionado las primeras horas del juego y notarÃ¡s como se va desarrollando este conforme avanzas en el juego.
I loved gunning down the vox sympathizers in the shantytown and the jail cells

Bioshock 1 had a good setting that was original, aesthetically pleasing, intellectually intriguing, and essentially a mysterious place that you wanted to slowly unravel. The audiologs gave you insight into the people's lives and thoughts there, and piece by piece you puzzled together what happened there and what lead to it; among other things. Items were satisfying to find, combat was also satisfying and sufficiently interspersed, and plasmids were new and their reason for existing was a fundamental part of the story.

Bioshock 2 was "more of the same" with improved mechanics. Some people loved it, some people hated it; for me the story was worse, but the mechanics were better so gameplay-wise it was more fun to play (and the story itself wasn't bad either, it just didn't live up to the masterpiece-level of Bioshock 1).

And then comes Bioshock Infinite. I played this game to completion when it first came out 7 years ago (pirated), and before it was released I followed it closely and with hype. There's 1 word that can describe this entire game: "forced". They tried to create a new Bioshock from thin air, but in the sky. Instead of creating a game from scratch, one that is cohesive, they forced a template (the Bioshock template), then built a game around it that didn't fit. The result was this strange "Frankenstein" monster. For example; there's vigors in this game (the plasmid equivalent), which make ZERO sense story-wise and are completely superfluous and an "after-thought"; simply shoved in because it's a Bioshock gameplay staple. Given the setting, they are not believable; and the setting itself is also unbelievable. A city under the sea? Sure. A floating city? Nope, especially not the way it's set up; as a kind of dissociated building archipelago, and much less in its time period. Also, while Rapture is enthralling due to its setting and you are constantly reminded of where you are due to the windows etc.; most of the time in Columbia you couldn't even tell that you're actually "floating in the sky", it looks like a regular city. You can see sky above you, so it's not as obvious a reminder as seeing water above you.
The story, related to the "tears" (won't spoil anything), is not that great; it's bombastic and overblown, and you are also force-fed it throughout the game. The rest of the story the setting justifies itself with is generic garbage as far as I can tell, as is the clichÃ©d revolutionary side-arc and the reminders that "racism bad"; the audiologs are boring and completely unappealing. While in Bioshock 1 I loved seeing an audiolog at any point, here these were a drag. About finding items, as opposed to Bioshock 1 where the city was in shambles and you could just go taking the few items you could find with the "justification" of someone who takes something from a building in ruins as nobody will claim it and those who will are either way all trying to kill you, in this game the city is NOT in shambles and yet you take everything (which is MUCH more than you could even find in previous games) you can find, even steal it right in front of people's faces with no consequence (there's a couple of instances in the game where if you steal you will be attacked, but they are the minority). Petty theft simulator 2013.
The game is overlong. Most of it is combat, and despite the vigors and sky-lines, the combat is very boring and repetitive. The AI is dumb as a rock, barely has any moves at all (not pretty for a game that relies so heavily on combat). Weapons aren't that many, and you can only hold 2 at the same time; which wouldn't be that big of a deal if combat weren't CENTRAL to the game.
This might be a nitpick, but: Elizabeth can find money for you. When she does, you can accept it by pressing E (you must eventually accept it). Every time you do, an animation showing her throwing you a coin and you looking at it, is triggered. It's not skippable. If this animation were triggered once, it would be no problem (it lasts about 2 seconds). But you see it so many times during the game, that you can feel the time-waste. It's too long. The game should play it in full the 1st time, then give you a shortened or sped up version of it afterwards.

To end on a positive note, the positives of this game in my view are the sky-lines; they are very fun to use during combat. And also the tears during combat: Essentially, Elizabeth can bring forth specific items (RPG barrels, medkit crates, flying turrets to shoot enemies, rocket launcher automatons, etc.), etc; but only one at a time. It's "resource-management" during the combat, and it spices up the fight.
Also, Elizabeth as a companion is pretty useful. She will look for things in the map that you might need; if you run low on salts (which you need to use the powers, called vigors), and she sees salts somewhere, she will get them and call your attention, after which you can press E so she throws the item at you for instant use. Same for medkits, ammo, and money.
If you feel attached to Elizabeth and her plight, you will like the story. The Elizabeth-related story isn't too bad, it's just overblown.
The game is a "bad good game". A game that makes you wanna play it, yet doesn't live up to its potential. Buy Bioshock 1 and 2 instead of this one, and maybe also play this one once if you liked the previous ones; but if you expect the same level of quality or engagement, you'll probably be disappointed.

El juego base pierde los aspectos caracteristicos del bioshock 1 y 2, como son el sigilo, recursos limitados y terror, yendo a un genero shooter mas clasico lo que en cierta medida le quita la gracia pero esto se ve compensado con una narrativa excelsa; una historia concebida para mantenerte siempre atento y con grandes sorpresas que descubrir. El juego cumple desde el punto de vista tecnico, grafico, narrativo y argumental. No digo nada que no se haya dicho ya realmente, un excelente juego, incluso si no eres amante de los shooter como yo, lo terminaras disfruntando bastante. Los DLC los veo netamente necesarios ya que cierra el argumento que se te venia contando y aclara varias dudas que si o si te quedaran en el juego base, asi que si tienes la posibilidad de comprar los DLC, compralos!.
It is a good game, not as imersive, or interesting, or interesting as the first one, but a really enjoyable game. I`ve been enjoying the shooting and is beautifull, with ocasionally great songs.
